commentBody:
"How'd you serve that ice cream so quickly?"
"I've got scooper powers."

(It was a sherbet I'd post this.)

PEKOE is a Tea Musa for me, along with assam. 

Wait, that's not how I'm supposed to parse 51A??? ;)

There has been some discussion recently in these comments about whether solvers pay attention to the theme while solving.

Here, the answers came to me so fast (though not quite as fast as the Monday puzzle) that there was no pause in which I stopped to consider what was in the shaded squares.

When I finished, I saw V, OV, OOV, and OOOV.  I thought, "Wha...?"  And then I said, let me look at the reveal again, since I didn't get past the [Eagerly obtained...] part of it.

And then I noticed:  Ice cream cones.  SCOOOOOOOPED UP.  I get it.

But I didn't need any of this theme to solve the puzzle. So it was basically a very fast themeless with a post-solve lagniappe at the end.
I predict spurs (being attachments to, not part of) boots will be this puzzle's hemoglobin

Must not have been too hard since I was one minute above my Tuesday PR even after a couple drinks, but a fun puzzle.

The only square I had to brute force was ALTA / ATE.  Because I've never heard of ALTA and I didn't get the 'side' clue until after.
This crossword was 23D.

If you are unfamiliar with the American tv ad where the punchline is I go cuckoo for Cocoa Puffs then you may struggle with Goes cuckoo for. 4:35 seconds faster than my Tuesday average. Enjoyed the puzzle but had to look 3x before understanding the reveal. Had sole before spur so o-ko- wasn’t making any sense at first.

Easy solve, with a useless and questionable -not to mention lame - "theme". 

V standing in for a cone, with Os pretending to be scoops of ice cream ... maybe. Just barely maybe, but maybe.

But what has an empty cone got to do with a tall order? (Or, for that matter, either a single or double scoop)? 

There's no connection from either revealer to the idea that the order gets taller through the puzzle.

Colour me unimpressed.

My local ice cream shop recently opened a new location here in town that serves only frozen yogurt. It’s a self service deal - pay at the end based on weight.

Now, I love taking the kids to ice cream for an occasional treat. They pick two flavors - most times they seem to  complement each other. Sometimes they’ll get a topping that ties it together. Delicious. Refined. Wonderful.

But frozen yogurt is a different beast all together. The kids go CUCKOO. They fill big tubs with all sorts of nasty flavor combos and candy. 

There’s something unholy about mixing watermelon sorbet with chocolate peanut butter swirl, topping it with marshmallows, sour worms, and whatever else is within arm’s reach of the sneeze guard. It’s not a dessert. It’s a *crime scene*. 

So, between you and me, I’m not taking them to froyo anymore. I’m not depriving them. I’m guiding them back to civilization. They’ll thank me one day. Until then, they’ll have to suffer through a delicious

O
O
V
I could be wrong, but I'm pretty sure an orca isn't a deep sea predator...?
This was fun, thank you.

Has the editorial staff ditched the animations for puzzles like this? This time I wasn’t necessarily expecting it, but it certainly would have made the theme more understandable without having to read the Wordplay column. And doesn’t 16A only really apply to the “cone” at 43D? The others would seem like normal orders to me.

On a happy note, that was my best Tuesday solve time (8:21) - a full 16:53 faster than my average! I would say that puzzle was definitely in my wheelhouse!

@Grumpy

Grumpy, did you wake up on the wrong side of the bed today?  I thought the puzzle was delightful.  And I’ll also add that as someone who tends to view things quite literally, I actually took the time to Google “ov, oov, ooov” and I’m not embarrassed to admit that.  Even knowing “tall order” and “scooped up” I was still looking at the puzzle in a literal sense, rather than seeing it figuratively.  I was about to visit the Urban Dictionary, naturally assuming that  middle-aged me didn’t get the memo on these new texting terms!  But your criticism seems so unwarranted.  It was an ice cream theme.  It’s summertime.  Who doesn’t love  ice cream?

🧵 I have to say, I’m NOT much of a fan of the recently introduced “ME” section.

I don’t NEED that “Welcome back, [player alias]” popup THING.  I know who I am!

I was doing just fine BEFORE, without any NEW software jazz to get used to.  But leaving that aside:

Today I learned how DIFFERENTLY the crossword stats are presented, and they will certainly have to be corrected:

Unlike before, where EACH DAY was shown with a very readable vertical BAR GRAPH, of AVERAGE, THIS WEEK, and BEST, now that easily readable format has been CHANGED to individual horizontal bars, AND THEY JUMP MARKEDLY from stat to stat, 😒‼️

FOR EXAMPLE, my Tuesday AVERAGE TIME is 20:43.  So far, so good.  BUT THEN, I tap on the THIS WEEK graph, and it says I solved today’s puzzle in 12:39 minutes, but it LOOKS LIKE I took about AN HOUR, compared to my average, because the horizontal bar is about 3️⃣ times longer than the AVERAGE.  And the same visual miscues exist when I want to see my BEST times.

You have GOT to fix this backward step in your crossword stats.  IT’S JUST NUTS!

Does anyone else agree?

Found an article from the NYT back in 2017.  It should give people a chance to enjoy themselves without feeling guilty.

“Crosswords are ultimately learning tools, whether you’re learning some trivia or an interesting new word or phrase. When you look something up, you’re learning so you’ll know it for next time.

Of course, some solvers may tell you that looking up the answer to a clue is “cheating,” but to us, that way lies frustration and a path to giving up. And that’s no fun. Crosswords are a game, and games are supposed to be fun.

Still not sure looking things up is fair? Here is outright permission:

“It’s your puzzle. Solve it any way you like.” — Will Weng, the second crosswords editor of The New York Times (1969 — 1977)”

- - Deb Amlen.
You gotta love an ice cream puzzle during the dog days of summer! WHEE🍧🍦🍨 I'll take the triple scoop thank you. No calories in crossword ice cream.
I enjoyed the theme.   Now I need an ice cream cone.
Maybe the wording of the clue is throwing me for 25 across, but was Shirley Chisholm not the first female presidential candidate for a major party?

I needed surprisingly long to deal with the NE corner - had it not been for it, I would have solved the puzzle in Monday time. SPUR and SOUTH were my only toeholds there.

I've been drinking tea all my life but I'm no tea snob (I'm happy with Dilmah tea bags), so PEKOE was no gimme. I've never had an opportunity to learn microwave lingo - it's not something that features in films or on tv, and I've never lived in an English language household. Thus, NUKE wasn't obvious, either. I thought the building block clue would be literal, since it's Tuesday. The whole corner unlocked for me when I finally came up with SCUSE ME - crosses from it and SOUTH gave me ATOM and WHEE, and it was smooth sailing from there.

The theme was fine. I once did many "drawings"  with my keyboard, and the theme reminded me of it. My best creations were Darth Vader ([:< and Princess Leia @^|^@

Darth Vader eating a TALL ORDER of ice cream? ([:< OOO>

I think only McDonald's operates drive-thrus in Poland. I never understood the point. On the extremely rare occasions I eat fast food, at all (usually on the road), I find it much more convenient to get out of the car and eat at a table than struggle to communicate over that crackling speaker and then risk getting food all over my clothes and upholstery 🤷

i'd like to brag i recognized the ice creams as soon as i got "goes cuckoo over" and noticed the similarity of the o-v shape in the middle which was completely filled out. then i was more confident that vying was a word, so i filled that in to get the third ice cream. from there i figured out "tall order" and "scooped up" and i was able to finish the puzzle quite fast for someone who usually has to use auto-check on any non-monday puzzle

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/07/21/tuesday-july-22-2025/#ny There's ice cream in the freezer and my husband is away for the night. Time to exercise a little discipline. Thanks, Mr. Newton!

As if we needed additional evidence of my impairment, when I saw SCOOPEDUP, I took the O..V segments to be some variant of “Hoover” (the vacuum cleaner, not the US president), especially because 8D ends in ER 😝

Spent too much time around Brits for whom “hoover” is a verb …

Staring at the grid post-solve per Sam’s suggestion got me to the ice cream cones.  

Quick but fun one today.  Thanks!

Mark
Good puzzle but Pekoe is a tea grade not a variety such as Assam or Darjeeling.

I didn't yet know it was a double scooped ice cream cone but filling it in in 24D on the basis of Vs with varying numbers of Os on top gave me that answer and led me to correct a couple of errors I had made in that part of the puzzle, so the "theme" was important for me.

My fastest, easiest solve yet. I barely stopped. 
Knowing some of the old faithfulls from earlier crosswords helped - IPAS, CPA, EPEE and I even knew HRC since that was fairly recent.
So pleased to be able to solve without eg sport/rap/film star clues that I didn't even notice some squares were shaded.

Past tense of sew I would say, is sewn, unlike sow/sowed seeds.

Lovely.
Almost set a new PB for Tuesday, but got tripped up in the NE. Still well below average
PB! I, like others, had ASSAM instead of PEKOE, so NE tripped me up. Still - fun, easy, and rewarding.

Surprisingly quick solve for me too (close to a Tuesday PB) but the reveal wasn't apparent until I peeked (pekoed?) at the accompanying comments. Nice work. Gives me more time to solve today's Tiles which nearly killed me yesterday

If the quote in the clue for 30D can actually be attributed to Cicero and not a bumper sticker from a yoga retreat, I’ll eat any of my hats: editor’s choice as to which one. (Except for my original Utah Utes hat; that one is a collectible by now. Or the Alta hat. Also vintage by now.)
Easy puzzle; but had to come to the article to see the theme!  Maybe it's just too early in the morning for me.
I see I’m not the only one who went ‘huh?’ at the reveal. Once Sam explained it, it was of course obvious.  Charming.
apparently NYT forgot that Shirley Chisholm ran for president.   disappointing.
Very cute, seasonal theme that made me think of Tom Waits "Ice Cream Man": https://youtu.be/YCoRoqGz5so?si=KqXcrB1RCQ2NCMnz
Shouldn't the clue for 32D be "Vampire bat features", plural?

I love ice cream for breakfast.
Or any time. I just love ice cream.
Mom says those were my first words, ice cream. Perhaps she exaggerates, but the cone-shaped sign at the frozen custard stand down the road was definitely the first symbol I knew.

I'm driving up to see Mom this week, she'll be 96 on Sunday.
So I'll be mostly off-line and out of crossword land for a fortnight.
Gahhh thought I had my first Tuesday until the cross of Utah ski resort and took a side. Still not quite sure on the answer for that as ate…?

Completed the puzzle in about the same time as I should have for a Tuesday. It was easy to figure out that each new theme answer would have an extra "O" added to it. In the end, though, I didn't get the theme until I read Rex's blog, which I always do before Wordplay. Then it was OHHHHH! Slap on the forehead.

I guess that because as a very chubby kid and for most of my teen years, I never ever had more than a single scoop, a practice that I seem to have continued for a lifetime as I sought to maintain a big weight loss when I was 19. (Jahn's Ice Cream Parlor for you old New Yorkers doesn't count, since their Kitchen Sink was shared my many!)
Thanks Jeremy. From the depths of winter, a summer treat.

The little micro-creamery we owned 
for a dozen years is helping me out this week!

When we began, we had a toddler.
The second year, a toddler and an infant.
So they grew up in an ice cream parlor.

We knew we needed a plan.
Neither of us wanted to monitor how
much they ate. 

So they had carte blanche to have at it.
The cream, brownies, toppings, sauces…

Our eldest was 4 when he realized three scoops
gave him a bellyache, 
and four was utterly regrettable.

So 2 scoops it was!

For their birthdays they asked for
pasta, chicken, salads, veggies…
No cake. No ice cream.

Is there a lesson here?
Dunno!

Have a terrific Tuesday all!
Oh, ice cream! I didn’t get it. Enjoyed the puzzle anyway.  It would have been fun and informative to throw in some classic ice cream flavors. Overall this puzzle was more VANILLA than ROCKYROAD.

This just in:

I have no idea what playground has ever heard that particular lead-in to DOTOO.

Sometimes, people put umbrellas in a crock.  Nonsense, you say? They don’t? DOTOO.

Well, it's hard not to like a July puzzle who's theme is ice cream.

Can't say I was wowed by the visuals. Too bad the appropriate O's didn't turn into solid whites, browns, pink, etc. upon completion of the puzzle.

Clues like "Something to feed a steed" for the singular OAT always make me smile. The image of offering a single oat groat to a majestic half-ton horse is priceless.

Not sure why any constructor/editor would opt for FATE/OAT rather than, say, FAKE/OAK---except possibly to make folks like me smile. So thanks for that.

I scream, you scream, we all scream for ice cream.* 

Where was I. Oh yeah - just a bit tough for a Tuesday but worked it all out, and must confess that I had to ponder for a bit before I completely got it, because I was trying to see how the two long across answers fit the theme. I guess they don't. No big deal. 

Odd puzzle find today - vaguely inspired by 'SCOOPEDUP' - a Thursday from October 28, 2010 by David J. Kahn. Five theme answers in that one, all clued in relation to each other: 

WHATISA
GHOSTSFAVORITE
DESSERT

BOOBERRYPIEAND
ISCREAM

And a rather remarkable puzzle find that I'll put in a reply. 

....

This puzzle has the stamp of quality.  A fun visual theme, excellently presented, amidst a just-right Tuesday answer set and clue level.  From start to end, I felt as if I were in the hands of a craftsperson.

Not to mention that this is the perfect puzzle to counter the heat of a very hot summer.  A pick-me-up.

Theme echoes all over: EAT ME, BEACH, ORB, MENU, and even I LOVE YOU SO MUCH and GOES CUCKOO OVER.

SHINE in the box as well, with the lovely HAVOC, ONYX, GNAW, and TALL ORDER.

This is the second day in a row with a terrific theme, after yesterday’s GOTTA CATCH ‘EM ALL, and Jeremy is all about theme – not a themeless among his 29 Times puzzles.

Joy in the box today, and a splendid outing.  Thank you, Jeremy!

DOH moment. I was so sure the orders were coffee sizes that while I dutifully filled in the O's, it didn't click. Guess I hadn't had enough coffee yet.
I'm sure I could never manage a triple scoop. As in the Judith Viorst book, "Alexander and the No Good Horrible Very Bad Day", the ice cream part would fall off the cone part and land in Australia.
A conical confection.
Such a cute theme, thoroughly enjoyed this one. Happy Tuesday!

Very important to finish this puzzle quickly.

Before it melts.

Spurs and cowgirl boots.
Wow. Two errors in one clue.
Spurs are not a part of cowboy boots, they are an accessory worn with cowboy boots.
It is strapped to the boot, not part of it.

Cowgirls wear cowboy boots. 

Read a Wikipedia page.
Excellent Tuesday, good difficulty and cute theme.
New personal best Tuesday at 5:41. Been an easy start to the week.
Okay, I didn't get the theme until after I finished, but once I did, I said, "OMG, that is so cute." It brightened my morning.
I lapped it up! Yum!
new fastest time! 5:08

Hmm...  it took me a minute! 
Excuse for fuzzy-brain:   I'm just back from my walk--it was 80 degrees at 6:15 this morning, with 96% humidity.  I'm having some coffee to cool down.
How long would a triple SCOOP cone last ....splat!

DHubby has brought home some (purportedly lactose-free) ice cream which is passable...but what I wouldn't give for some fresh peach ice cream straight from the old freezer bucket!  (No cone necessary.)  It would be worth it...

Nice tie-ins with CAPE (May?) BEACH, TALL ORDER, and EAT ME.
On with the day!

Loved the theme, especially as we've got a heat advisory today.

A-PLUS!

Random question: Does anyone remember who the constructor was on a Sunday puzzle a few years ago that had traffic lights in the grid?  

I tried to find the puzzle on xwordinfo.com, but short of looking at every Sunday grid from 2021–2023, I haven’t had any luck. 

Thanks.
Solved this one line by line - and delighted to see the ice cream cone pattern at the end…what fun!🍦☀️

Deliciously cute!

I thought the Vs and Os looked like someone juggling ping-pong balls with their mouth.

Todays LA Times crossword theme pairs quite well with this one.

In addition to reminding me of a favorite song, this puzzle reminds me of a favorite album cover: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Such_Great_Heights#/media/File:The_Postal_Service-Such_Great_Heights.jpg

What a great puzzle, especially for this hot summer. Was able to fill in every square without lookups (a rarity these days). That makes it so much more fun. The theme revealed itself when the puzzle was done. Yum, yum. My favourite flavours in a multi-scoop cone are dark chocolate and maple walnut. How about you?

Congrats to the constructor. More, please!
Umbrella clue fooled me a bit.  Had stand for the longest time.
I thought a lot of the clues were unnecessarily wordy, using three or four or five words when one or two would do just fine.
Loved the puzzle. Didn’t get the theme til I read Ms. Corbins note. 🤦🏻‍♀️  Thought it was cute once I saw it. A lovely Tuesday. Thanks!
if ROAM/ROVE is in a crossword, I am certain to choose the wrong one every time

What are we doing here? TV Guide level puzzles?

Orcas are found more commonly near coastlines and, since they are mammals, aren’t exactly “deep sea” hunters. 

Stipulating that Odin is Thor’s dad in both myth *and* the Marvel Universe is, frankly, obtuse. The Marvel Universe Thor is based squarely on the Thor of Norse myth. C’mon. 

It’s like the crosswords are being aimed at a 10-year-old audience.

I'll take 3 scoops, please and thank you.

In 2020, I did a lot of hiking in the White Mountains, and I rewarded myself with ice cream from the New Hampshire Ice Cream Trail, traveling all over the state.

I finished the trail and got a sweatshirt for my efforts. Would do it again if I didn't hate driving.
Not paying attention to the tense of "SHOOK it to the beat" got me to the point where I had to autocheck the whole puzzle for one letter, because "So Too" made sense as a comeback to me

Cute puzzle today.  Nice theme for a summer Tuesday.

On a different note, was there a Midi today?  Yesterday we were promised a week's worth with a phrase from letters from the week's puzzle.  I can't find it anywhere.
If you enjoyed Erik Agard’s Saturday puzzle, he has a very nice one in The New Yorker today. It might be a little easier than his Saturday puzzle.
Liked the puzzle, but wasn’t there a similar ice cream cone-themed puzzle using Vs and Os the same way somewhat recently?  Felt like deja vu…
Very enjoyable puzzle!
Gosh, this was fun. The majority of it was very sweet and colloquial, a nice contrast to sharp facts and figures of post-Wednesday puzzles.

Sam Corbin is not alone. I too missed the obvious.

Fortunately, I do not lose my glasses on my head because I wear them on a string around my neck. But the wallet in my purse, yes.

I enjoyed the puzzle, and the theme, when I finally figured it out. But . . . I know I'm not supposed to be this picky about clues, but I felt a few were misleading. 
A SPUR is not part of a boot but an add-on to it. 
PEKOE is not a variety of tea but a grade of tea; any variety of black tea (Assam, Darjeeling, Nilgiri, etc.) can be graded as pekoe. It has to do with leaf size. 
An ORCA is not a deep-sea predator so much as a near-the-surface predator. 
Yeah. Come at me. It's okay.
Meh ...

My usual late puzzle find. Stumbled across this because of something in the news. Anyway - a Tuesday from April 24, 2007 by Brendan Emmett Quigley. Theme answers in that one: DIZZYDEAN FUZZYZOELLER OZZYOSBOURNE JAZZYJEFF Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/24/2007&g=44&d=A ...
8D and 13D are perfect for me today because today is my wonderful 58A husband's birthday today and both of those are spot-on!! 😍

Loved this puzzle and loved the theme, though, like Sam, I finished it without quite understanding what the vertical V’s and O’s were doing. I was so glad she explained. I never manage to read ALL the comments, but I did see that some others didn’t quite figure it out and some did, so I’m happy. And as usual, some thought it was too easy.

userLocation: Boston suburbs and south coast MA
commentBody:
Well, I’m feeling dense for not getting the theme on my own…But fun to see it after the fact.

I never crave or want ice cream until it’s presented to me, and then I wonder why I don’t have it every day. I was recently introduced to salted caramel with (the old cruciverbial fave) Oreo chunks. Utter genius 🤯!
Sam Lyons: The Wednesday WSJ puzzle has a literary theme that you will probably breeze through if you're so inclined.

Apologies if already answered -
Any help on how/where to access today's Midi puzzle? Thanks, friends.

Finally a clue for UFOs I can completely get behind. Not only does it acknowledge those that think it's ETs, it also includes the possibility of a completely terrestrial explanation.

Thanks!
Cute theme! Now I’ll go get some ice cream.
This is an amazingly fun puzzle! Nicely manageable for a Tuesday and such a clever theme. 10/10 from me!

@Mike
I cone't. I just cone't.

@Mike

You might say that was a cold shot.

@Mike
Sorry, I don’t want to be a dip, so I’ll split.

@Mike

Serving up puns
Divertentissimo,
It's our hero Mike
Intelligentissimo.
His wordplay pizzicato,
Glissando, stacatto!  
Not too plain, not too bold 
Smooth parole gelato. 
No post is neutro,
Alla fine - cioccolato!

O
V

@Mike
I love how your puns are so spoontaneous !

@Mike
You tossed out a soft serve with that one.  Sundae you'll have one that's more challenging.

@Mike

Gnaw, it wasn't.

@Isabeau

Took me a bit t-oolong to get that. I had to go back to the  puzzle. Pretty aMUSAng!
@Steve L I never noticed a theme here. Too easy and quick to pick up the theme.

@Andy G

Just because it’s easy doesn’t mean you _have_ to solve it quickly. You can linger, if you choose

@Alexis

I just loved reading your comment!  Cheers!

Interesting. When I solve, I like to read the entire clue even if I get the answer quickly, and I like to look for themes. After reading the first revealer at 16A, I watched the shaded squares as I filled them. I had a good idea what the second revealer would reveal before I got to it. I'm in no rush to finish, and my ice cream didn't melt.

@Chris

Growing up outside of Boston, I was very lucky that I learned to ski at ALTA, because my uncle was living in Salt Lake City at the time. Much nicer than the "icy granular" of northeastern slopes, especially when one falls a lot learning! And of course a much taller mountain with longer runs than our "local" Mt. Wachusett...

@G

I learned to ski in Vermont in the late 1960s. Then my family moved twice, eventually to Dallas. I didn't ski again until 1992, when I took my husband to Bromley, Vermont.

It wasn't until 2004 that we went with a friend to Park City, Utah. I'd never skied in real powder. 

We've been going back to the Wasatch every year since then (except for the 2020–2021 season).

@Chris

"I've never heard of ALTA . . ."

You must be new here.

The resort has been in the puzzle many times, most recently 6/9/25, 1/20/25 and 5/30/24.

Congratulations on your almost PR, though.

@Dave K.

I see that as A PLUS.
@dutchiris I think you mean 58A.

@Dave K.

Yup.
@Grumpy   It's how a tall order is made. Start with an empty cone and add one scoop, then another on top of that, and so on. With only letters to work with the idea works.

@Grumpy

From someone who has scooped 
over 2100 cones in a single day,

it works.

You start with a v-shaped cone,
and as the order gets taller,
the circular balls of frozen goodness
stack up…up…up!

And not for nothin, 
but getting a triple or quadruple scooper
to be structurally solid is an art.

I’ll die on this hill.

@Grumpy

I get the theme, but I do agree with you that “tall order” is a stretch (no pun intended). You can do a tall order of beer, and literally a tall order of coffee if that’s what they call their size, but go into an ice cream shop and ask for a tall order of ice cream and they will think you are pretty weird. I suppose literally it’s a tall order (you do order it, and a triple scoop is tall) but if you are going to have a pretty basic theme like this I agree that the top revealer should have more to do with ice cream (I do like SCOOPEDUP though).
@Grumpy Can't wait to see your next submission!

@Striker

Bravo!  But I’ll just add that if I had been one of your kids, you wouldn’t have opted for that configuration with me!   As kids, our parents would take us to Carvel for soft ice cream — are they even still around? — and while everyone else got cones, slowpoke me was only allowed a cup!  Chocolate soft ice cream with chocolate sprinkles.  By the time I was finished, it was pure liquid mush!  And I loved it!  I still recall enjoy eating my ice cream slow and melty!

@Diane Schaefer

Carvel is still around. My friends' daughter lives in Queens, NY and bought her a Carvel cake from a free-standing Carvel store last week. They sell the cakes in supermarkets there, too.

@Striker I went to Junior High in Queens and had to take two buses home.  One of the stops where I had to change buses was at a Carvel store.  If I timed it right, I could have a Carvel soft cone between buses.

@Striker

I have to admit that I was a bit of a “late bloomer” as far as ice cream was concerned.  Come to think of it, that applied to food of any sort.  I was a very picky eater.  And I remember distinctly turning down ice cream, of all things, at age 5 or 6 when my tonsils were removed!  But by age 10, I had indeed fallen in love with Carvel soft chocolate ice cream.  Just thinking about it makes my mouth water.  I’m sure memories of Fentons do the same for you!

@Eli
According to Wikipedia, they will dive several hundred feet if pursuing prey. (Though do spend most of their time in shallow waters.)

@Eli yes I picked up on that too. According to ChatGPT an ORCA is "a marine apex predator that hunts primarily in shallow to mid-depth ocean waters, often near coastlines or on the continental shelf"

That being said I still enjoyed the puzzle 😋🍨🍦

@Eli As a marine mammal scientist and orca enthusiast, I absolutely agree with you.   Even if they dive a little deeper to pursue prey, it’s not where they are hunting for prey. Sperm whales, on the other hand, are deep-sea predators, diving up to 2 miles deep to hunt for prey. Orcas don’t even come close to anything like that. “Apex ocean predator” would have been a much better clue.

I felt that clue was off. Thank you all for your posts. I know I could always google orcas, but learning about them from your posts feels much more human 👍🏾

Btw. GBoard (Google keyboard app) emoji search just pleasantly surprised me: it doesn't show the whale and dolphin emoji for a "fish" search, but it does for a "mammal" one. 🐋🐬 🦔 (The hedgehog's there because they're cute and I love them. We used to run into them all the time on night-time walks with Jorge the Lab)

@Eli I was going to post that but I knew I would get nit-picked. There was a study which found an orca diving to 1,087 meters in search of Patagonian Toothfish. https://hakaimagazine.com/news/a-record-breaking-dive-by-a-hungry-killer-whale/ So I guess it's fair game for the crossword.
@Cherry. I saw it as a single cone being stacked. That is, a single TALL ORDER

@Heidi

As a grump myself, I will always stand up for grumpy people 🙃

@Andrzej

I disagree. Shouldn’t our minimum expectation of civility be to use the same language in our comments as we would directly in person? If you were standing around, chatting in person with Mr. Newton (constructor) and Grumpy, and Grumpy blatantly insulted Mr. Newton by saying his puzzle was lame, I hope you too would come to Mr. Newton’s defense. I don’t think this forum is any different. Everyone is certainly welcome to their own opinion, but expressing opinions in an anonymous insulting way is not civil. I might think in my mind that your shirt is ugly, but I’m not going to blurt it out unsolicited.

@Steve

Meh, I wrote a long and civil reply to you but emus quashed it. Synopsis:

Online commenting =/= talking in person

@Andrzej Nuke is both a good and bad analogy for microwave heating.
Microwave ovens heat with radio frequency (RF) waves at a certain wavelength that happens to react with water to cause heating.
Nuclear fission also produces RF waves, typically x-rays or gamma rays. These however carry 1 million or more times more energy than microwaves. So much energy it can blow electrons off of atoms - which is called ionizing radiation.
Microwaves can't do that, so they're called non-ionizing radiation.
Non-ionizing radiation can cause severe burns in people (and other living things), while ionizing radiation can cause cancer and other very nasty effects.
So the difference between microwaving and actually nuking is in large part a matter of the energy levels involved.
In my book, the similarities totally justify calling microwaving "nuking", which we do in my household.

@HeathieJ

These past few years I've rediscovered Poland as a destination for travel. I ignored it for decades - the rest of the world seemed so much more interesting! However, in 2023 I went for a short trip with my father (our first holiday together in ages) around Dolny Śląsk, Lower Silesia. It's roughly the the SW corner of Poland, with a rich history, mostly as part of Germany (before 1945 Poles had ruled there until the middle of the 14th century). The castles, the towns, the food, the beer, the winding mountain roads, the forests - it was amazing, as good as anything I've experienced elsewhere in Europe.

The decades of "communism" left their ugly mark, of course, in places, but Poland is well worth seeing. 

I also recently realized Warsaw - which I had dismissed as a messy, uninteresting place for most of my life - is a fascinating city, in some respects similar to Berlin. Horribly scarred by WW2, it came back to life, and after a few ugly, chaotic decades following the fall of the old regime in 1989, at present it is thriving: what monuments are left have been meticulously [the spelling of this word! sheesh!] restored, hundreds of thousands of new trees have been planted (on top of the millions already there), the city center is being made pedestrian-friendly after decades of automotive horror, and there are great cafes, bars, and restaurants everywhere. Public transport is A PLUS, there are loads of accommodations.

Do come visit.

A scaled-down and only slightly modified version of a NYT recipe by Yossi Arefi:
________

Fluffy Pumpkin Pancakes for Two

1 cup (5 oz.) All-Purpose Flour
4 tsp Sugar
1 tsp Baking Powder
½ tsp Baking Soda
½ tsp Kosher Salt
1 tsp Cinnamon
⅔ tsp Ginger
Pinch Nutmeg

½ cup Pumpkin Purée
1 Egg
2 tbsp. melted Butter
1 cup (8½ fl. oz.) Buttermilk
⅔ tsp. Vanilla Extract

Toasted Pecans

Step 1
Toast pecans, melt butter

Step 2
In a large bowl, whisk the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, salt and spices together until well combined

Step 3
In a medium bowl, whisk the buttermilk, pumpkin purée, eggs, melted butter and vanilla extract until well combined.

Step 4
Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and gently fold with a rubber spatula until just combined. (A few small lumps are O.K.)

Step 5
Heat a lightly greased griddle or nonstick skillet over medium heat. Drop the pancakes into the pan by the ¼ cup, making sure to leave plenty of room in between for the batter to expand.

Step 6
Cook for a minute or two, until the batter bubbles at the edges and browns on the bottom, then carefully flip. Cook another minute or two, until the batter is completely cooked through and the pancakes are puffy and deep golden brown. Repeat until all of the batter is used. Serve the pancakes as you make them or keep the pancakes warm as you cook them by setting them on a baking sheet in a 250-degree oven.

As for quote sites, anything that doesn’t site the source is a “quote” site. You’re at best getting an extremely diluted paraphrase. 

For quick, not in-depth academic searches, your best bet is Wikiquotes, which does cite sources (at least most of the time, I believe?)

Sources or it didn’t happen, as the kids always say. 

As for this particular Ciceronian “quote,” it’s too pat and vague to be his. The sentiment might be, but it doesn’t belong between quotation marks. It’s likely a product of the time-tested Fake Quote Formula:

1. Take a vague paraphrase of a real classical sentiment.
2. Remove the actual Latin.
3. Attribute it to [insert ancient orator].
4. Add a jpeg of a marble bust.
5. Claim two bonus IQ points.

@Linda Jo
My Great-grandfather was named Anderson Cicero Cantrell--a Methodist preacher in the North GA Conference (places like Flowery Branch, Young Harris, Hiwassee).  Maybe the name went to his head, as by all accounts he was a petty tyrant...

@Eric Hougland

When it comes to Classical authors, Cicero’s extant texts are unmatched in quantity. 

I can think of some letters Cicero wrote during his time in Greece under the tutelage of Molon, when he was learning to strip his rhetoric of unnecessary flourishes, that communicate roughly this sentiment. Then there is his Stoicism-influenced expounding on the principles of communication in De Oratore and De Officiis, but nothing that would translate like this quote. Again, he left behind a huge body of work, so it would take a lot of searching of all the possible versions of how this aphorism may have read in the original Latin to dispositively say it’s not his—which is why I won’t. But I am willing to bet. A lot. 

And yes, Wikiquotes is crowdsourced just like all the other quote sites, but it gives you a starting point because it provides a citation. You can then search through the primary source. I wouldn’t take anything straight off the web at face value.

Also, there is a human editor involved. Most other quote sites are clearly just AI-compiled amplification of other unverified sources.

@Sam Lyons, So . . . I couldn't read all these comments without going down the rabbit hole. 

From what I can find, it looks like the quote is actually from Hannah More, an 18th-19th-century religious writer and philanthropist. 

This is what she says: "That silence is one of the great arts of conversation is allowed by Cicero himself, who says, there is not only an art, but even an eloquence in it." 

I don't know where she got it from, but the way the sentence is constructed, it seems like Cicero actually wrote something closer to "there is not only an art, but even an eloquence in silence". More picked that up and added "that silence is one of the great arts of conversation".

@CCNY my mom owned a bakery when I was growing up. She allowed her kids as well as her employees to eat as much of anything they wanted. Perfect strategy as we were all sick of everything pretty quickly.

@CCNY In and after high school I had a job filling vending machines. The boss said I could have as much candy and soda as I wanted. (But I couldn't take any cigarettes, so that tells you how long ago this was.) it wasn't long before I didn't want very much.

@CCNY

In defense of only ever wanting vanilla ice cream, my mom always told the tale of working in an ice cream shop as a teen, saying it cured her of ever wanting more. 

So teenaged me thought I'd try the same treatment, and off I went to work at a local creamery. (I guess what you call a micro-creamery: there was only the one location. I still have the apron I -- ahem -- acquired during my tenure.) Well, what's good for the goose does not necessarily work for the gosling!

I still adore ice cream. And frozen treats, in basically all forms. 

Just in smaller portions... 😋

@Jacqui J

Oh, but croissants and fresh baked bread?

I will never grow tired of those.
Add pasta and strand me on a desert island!

@SSteve

I have heard it actually works with cigarettes, too.

You just have to smoke a whole pack at once.
When you’re done keeling over,
you’re not gonna jones for a smoke ever again!

@Mean Old Lady

I tried telling my kids that
a real breakfast was a warm meal.

Wasn’t careful about what I wished for,
as they already were off of the sweet train
(see original post), and
I persuaded them into wanting
savory breakfasts every day before 6:45.

What I’d give to back and 
feel a wee bit burdened by all that cooking and feeding…

*sigh*

@G

Ha! 
This is what my mother said!

Those days with the ice cream parlor,
she was in her sixties.
She’d waltz in, 
nudge the staff out of her way,
and make a dish of vanilla with 
hot caramel and salted pralines.

She’d still eat a bowl nightly if
she had her druthers…

@CCNY

I love that! 

And vanilla with hot caramel and salted pralines sounds divine! 


At that ice cream parlor, we served hot fudge so thick it took real muscle to push hard enough to get it through the pump. I'd end up with it everywhere, even inside my short sleeves! But I still love a true hot fudge such as that one...
@JohnWM Ditto. Very odd.
@George K. @JohnWM Kids seem to conjure up all kinds of playground retorts in the crossword, don't they? This one could be "I have magic powers." "Do not!" "DO TOO!" or some such.

Sam Corbin,

It’s not the retort that I question; it’s the pretort. 

Maybe upscale NYC playgrounds are rife with children saying “You have no idea!”  when asked if they have a crush on Suzie or Jimmie, or how hard the math test was, or whatever. If some kid had the wits to reply DO TOO to such a weird playground statement, I guess I’d give them full marks for meeting absurdity head on.
:)

@Xword Junkie

Oh. "whose"

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: a Sunday from March 31, 1968 by Frances Hansen with the title "Limerick trick." I have never seen another puzzle like this. Five long answers - the first one clued as "Start of a limerick" and all the others clued as "Limerick continued." Here are those answers: SAIDWSOMERSETMAUGHAMIS HALLVISITTHEISLANDOFGUA MIFIFINDITISHOTIS HALLLEAVEONTHESPOTIDETE STFEELINGOVERLYWAUGHAM Odd. Can't help but wonder how many people managed to work that one out. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/31/1968&g=79&d=D ....

@Rich in Atlanta TALL ORDER (like the last ice cream cone with three scoops, or even a single cone, since "taller" than wide) and SCOOPED UP (like the process of scooping ice cream) both fit the theme. In fact, SCOOPED UP was the answer that revealed to me that the gray squares were ice cream cones.
BTW -- I thought I'd seen a theme like this before, and a commenter on Rex confirmed it, a puzzle from six  years ago.  Worth a look in the archives: 9/4/2019.

@Kit

Hmmm..  interesting to see a comment from Kit right above a comment from someone with the surname Carson. 

Oh, and KITCARSON has been an answer in 3 puzzles. 

I'll shut up now.

@Marlene
But then you'll get that "brain freeze" head ache!  Beware!

@Mean Old Lady

Good point. Keep napkins handy! Or, a cat on your lap.

@Ken Burk I can’t parse the boot/accessory divide, but surely a [cowgirl’s boot] can withstand your critique? The cowgirl can possess a boot (cowboy boot or other) and not find herself totally erased, no?
Ken, (1) Your first objection was anticipated: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/491flg?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share (2) Even cowgirls get the boots.

@Ken Burk

I don’t know how y’all do things up in Illinois, but I’m a Southwestern girl who refers to the dozen or so pairs in her closet as cowgirl boots. Nothing wrong with calling them women’s cowboy boots, of course—Lucchese et al. do—but most women I know don’t.

@Barry Ancona

LLokl
LKol
lokk
LlKLoll
lokl
Lolk
llol
loll
lool

ugghgg hatee myy ffatt tthunbs

@Barry Ancona

Wow. Small world and all. 

At Sam Lyons’ recommendation, I poked around a little just now on the Wikiquotes website. Today’s featured quote is about technology vs. nature and is from Tom Robbins. 

I somehow missed the fact that he died a few months ago (or else I knew it at the time and forgot it, which seems unlikely). 

I was sorry to learn that not-so-new news. It’s been years since I have read any of his books, but I remember enjoying “Even Cowgirls Get the Blues” and “Skinny Legs and All.”
@Sam Lyons https://youtu.be/ESGscrjk4Pw?si=jfN6yNC5qHdEAu8g

@Eric Hougland

I dunno, Eric. To my mind, yodeling smacks more of “The Sound of Music” than an Amarillo cattle ranch, don’t you think?
@Ken Burk I’ve always gotten car accessories at my dealer’s parts department, but maybe that was foolish of me!

@Sam

I wear men's cowgirl boots.

@Ken Burk. Many years ago I worked for a company that made very, very expensive men's ties.  There was a job opening in the design department,  and one woman showed up wearing boots with spurs. (And a mini skirt, and rainbow eyeshadow.) Who knows? She may have been great, but she flunked the culture test.

@Sam Lyons Not so much bluegrass, but old country. Here's what's probably the earliest solo female artist to have hit it big (in 1935): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rAYwYscqXJQ That's 90 years ago, so definitely before any of us were around. But then again, LeAnn Rimes put the same song out in 1994, when all of us were around: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=trJ610CgG68

@Mean Old Lady A few weeks ago, I decided to get an ice cream cone at a place famous for their HUGE scoops of ice cream.  It was a very hot day. I felt like a little kid trying to lick that ice cream cone faster than it was melting!  But, boy, was it ever good.
@Eric Hougland, there was one like that on Sunday, June 18, 2022. Here is the Wordplay: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/18/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2022-06-19.html

@Eric Hougland

Literally pasted your question into Google. Its A.I. gave:

Based on the information available, the New York Times crossword puzzle from June 19, 2022, titled "Some Light Reading," featured a theme of seven vertical, three-square-deep traffic lights within the grid. The constructor of this puzzle was Jeremy Newton. 

Better double check!
@Jill I just realized it was the same constructor as today’s puzzle, Jeremy Newton.  I suppose that’s why you were asking. Fun!
Eric, Here it is: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2022/06/19

@Jill

That’s the puzzle. Thanks!

@Xword Junkie

That’s the puzzle. Thanks!

@Barry Ancona

Thank you, Barry.

@sotto voce

Thanks.

@Dan
It's Tuesday. On Friday the same clue probably would have been shorter.
The extra words did not make the clues any easier to solve. They just made them longer to read and parse.

So you found them puzzling?

The nerve of them!

@Terry
There was a theme?  😏

@Calypso

That's why I always put in just the R and wait for crosses :D

@Eric Hougland

Tbh I'm not sure, I only remember the R, but who knows, my head is a mess 🤪

@Andrzej
I know the feeling. 🤪. I’m probably a lot older than you and there is dementia in my family, so it worries me. But I hear the same from younger people I know. Maybe it’s because we’re living in such crazy uncertain times? And I tell myself if I can still do puzzles every day things can’t be too bad.
@Byron It’s a Tuesday puzzle man. Be cool.

@Byron - ORCAs are trans-oceanic species. Sure, they are more often seen near coastline, in part because that is where most of the human observers are. But they are found waaaaaay out in the open ocean as well. 

You'd better believe that when the PNW salmon population heads out to sea, the ORCAs follow. Many of them, anyway. 

"Deep-sea" can mean something other than living at great depths, especially in a crossword, which you may be surprised to learn is not a treatise on cetacean biology. I used to go "deep-sea fishing" in my youth and I was definitely not dropping my line 3 miles down. And I wasn't diving at all. 

Comments like yours are the reason I rarely participate here any more.

@Paul Stoddard - There was a link to the new on in today's Games email messaage. 

I got there before I saw the message by altering the URL for yesterday's to today's date.
@Paul Stoddard https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/paid/midi-07-22-25?campaign_id=268&emc=edit_gp_20250722&instance_id=158711&nl=gameplay
Adam, Yes, somewhat recently. https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2019/09/04

@Adam I had the same question, and the answers were already waiting for me!

Laura,

I don't think anyone will come at you -- and it's late in the comments day -- but I hope you will scroll down to read discussions of the three answers you mention.
@Laura D if you’re nitpicking, I’ll add my own: Don’t people generally go cuckoo FOR and not OVER something? But the puzzle was so delightful I have to wave this off.

@Rich in Atlanta

R.I.P. Ozzy.

@HeathieJ

Happy birthday, Husband of HeathieJ! (I'm on my PC at the moment, so no proper emojis, please imagine my usual abundant set :D)

@HeathieJ,

Happy Birthday 🎂 to the World’s Luckiest Man 🏆!!!

@Kate

Do they have Kroger grocery stores in your area? They make a salted caramel ice cream with chocolate chunky things that are much better than any Oreo. It was our gp-to ice cream until we discover the chocolate peanut butter with fudgy swirls.

userLocation: Boston suburbs and south coast MA
commentBody:
@Eric Hougland

No Krogers near us, although I have lived in Kroger territory before. Perhaps best that I don’t have to fight another temptation;-).

@Whoa Nellie It seems like the only way to get there is through a link in an email they send. I have subscribed to the Games email which comes on Mondays and Wednesdays (I think). This week, they have declared it Midi Week to introduce this new puzzle. I believe that they will issue one puzzle per day (M-F) this week. Then, starting next week, it will be published once a week. Perhaps they are waiting until then to add it to the Games page/app. (I haven't been able to find it on the app or via the browser.) Here is the link from today's email: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/paid/midi-07-22-25 This page links you to the Newsletter content. The GamePlay newsletter is waaayyy near the bottom of the list: https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters?newsletter_signup=true&product_code=GP Enjoy!

@SuzyQ

Thanks!
